1.name: Awareness
1.description: You recognize the difference between busy and productive
1.milestone: Track your time for one week and identify your biggest time wasters

2.name: Foundation
capabilities: Maintain a simple task management system
Plan your day the night before
2.milestone: Complete one week using a consistent daily planning routine

3.name: Habit Builder
3.milestone: Maintain a morning routine for 30 consecutive days

4.name: Focus Practitioner
4.description: Reliably entering focused states for meaningful work
4.milestone: Average 2+ hours of deep work daily for a month

5.name: Systems Thinker
5.description: Building systems that make productivity automatic
5.milestone: Build a complete weekly system covering all responsibilities

6.name: Deep Worker
6.description: Deep work is your default mode of operation

7.name: Multiplier
7.description: Your systems multiply your personal output
7.milestone: Your systems produce results without daily involvement

8.name: Master Operator
8.description: Operating at peak effectiveness across all domains
capabilities: Integrate all life areas into coherent system
8.milestone: Others seek you out to learn your productivity methods

9.name: Flow State Artist
9.description: Entering and maintaining flow at will
9.milestone: Flow state is your default working mode

10.name: Productivity Master
10.description: Effortless, sustained high performance is your natural state
10.milestone: Your productivity philosophy influences others' systems

beginner.title: Time Audit Challenge
beginner.instructions: For one day, log every activity in 15-minute blocks. At the end, categorize each block: Deep Work, Shallow Work, Distraction, Recovery. Calculate your ratios.
beginner.success_criteria: Complete time log with category analysis and one insight about where time actually goes

beginner.title: MIT (Most Important Task) Practice
beginner.instructions: Before bed tonight, write down your ONE most important task for tomorrow. Do it first thing before checking email or messages. Repeat for 5 days.
beginner.success_criteria: 5 consecutive days of completing MIT before reactive work

beginner.title: Distraction Trigger Log
beginner.instructions: Each time you get distracted today, immediately write down: What you were doing, what triggered the distraction, and what you distracted yourself with. Review patterns at end of day.
beginner.success_criteria: Logged 5+ distraction events with triggers identified

intermediate.title: Deep Work Sprint
intermediate.instructions: Block 90 minutes with zero interruptions: phone in another room, notifications off, door closed. Work on one cognitively demanding task. Rate your focus 1-10 afterward.
intermediate.success_criteria: Complete 90-minute session with focus rating 7+ and meaningful progress on task

intermediate.title: Shutdown Ritual Creation
intermediate.instructions: Design and implement a shutdown ritual: capture incomplete tasks, review tomorrow's calendar, set MIT, explicitly say 'shutdown complete.' Practice for one week.
intermediate.success_criteria: Written shutdown ritual checklist used for 5+ consecutive workdays

intermediate.title: Habit Stacking System
intermediate.instructions: Identify 3 habits you want to build. Stack each onto an existing habit: 'After I [current habit], I will [new habit].' Write the formulas and practice for a week.
intermediate.success_criteria: 3 habit stacks designed and executed for 7 consecutive days

advanced.title: Time Block Your Entire Week
advanced.instructions: On Sunday, time-block your entire week: every hour assigned to a specific activity type. Include deep work blocks, shallow work batches, meetings, and recovery. Follow it and note deviations.
advanced.success_criteria: Complete week time-blocked in advance, followed with 80%+ adherence

advanced.title: Environment Design Audit
advanced.instructions: Evaluate your workspace: What triggers distraction? What's missing that would enable focus? Redesign the space for optimal deep work. Remove friction from good behaviors, add friction to bad ones.
advanced.success_criteria: Physical workspace redesigned with before/after photos and rationale

advanced.title: Build Your Personal Operating System
advanced.instructions: Document your complete productivity system: morning routine, daily planning, deep work protocol, communication batching, weekly review, shutdown ritual. Create a manual you could hand to someone else.
advanced.success_criteria: Written Personal Operating System document covering all productivity components

cross_module_connections.insight: Your income is capped by your ability to produce high-value output - deep work directly increases earning capacity
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Calculate your effective hourly rate during deep work vs shallow work. Use this to prioritize focus time.

cross_module_connections.insight: Productivity is as much about psychology as technique - inner resistance often sabotages outer systems
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: When you notice yourself avoiding deep work, journal: what emotion am I avoiding? Then do 25 minutes anyway.

cross_module_connections.insight: Energy management is more important than time management - you can't focus your way out of exhaustion
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Track your energy levels hourly for a day. Schedule your most important work for your peak energy windows.

cross_module_connections.insight: Environment shapes behavior more than willpower - design your space for focus rather than relying on discipline
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Identify 3 environmental changes that would make distraction harder and deep work easier. Implement today.

masters.name: Cal Newport
key_principles: Deep work is the ability to focus without distraction on a cognitively demanding task.
Clarity about what matters provides clarity about what does not.
If you don't produce, you won't thrive—no matter how skilled or talented you are.
The ability to perform deep work is becoming increasingly rare and increasingly valuable.
What we choose to focus on and what we choose to ignore—plays in defining the quality of our life.
Two core abilities for thriving: mastering hard things quickly and producing at an elite level.
daily_practices: Schedule 3-4 hours of uninterrupted deep work
Quit social media or severely limit it

worked_examples.title: The Deep Work Protocol
worked_examples.scenario: You have a demanding project but keep getting fragmented by messages, emails, and meetings.
step_by_step: Choose your deep work philosophy: rhythmic (same time daily), bimodal (dedicated deep days), journalistic (grab time when available)
Block your deep work time: Start with 90-minute sessions, build to 4 hours
Create a shutdown ritual: At session end, capture loose threads and officially close
Batch shallow work: Designate specific times for email, messages, admin
Protect ruthlessly: Treat deep work blocks as unmovable appointments
Track and celebrate: Log deep work hours weekly, aim for consistent increases
worked_examples.outcome: You accomplish in 4 focused hours what previously took 8+ scattered hours. Quality of work increases dramatically.

scripts_templates.title: Deep Work Shutdown Ritual Checklist
scripts_templates.context: Use at the end of each workday to close loops and release work from your mind
scripts_templates.template:
[ ] Check email one final time - respond or defer
[ ] Review task list - capture any new items
[ ] Check calendar for tomorrow - prep needed?
[ ] Identify tomorrow's #1 MIT
[ ] Review today's wins (even small ones)
[ ] Clear physical workspace
[ ] SAY OUT LOUD: 'Shutdown complete.'

NOTE: Once shutdown is complete, NO WORK THOUGHTS.
If a thought intrudes, tell yourself: 'I'll deal with that tomorrow.'
The ritual proves to your brain that loose ends are captured.
scripts_templates.example_filled:
[x] Email checked - 3 replied, 2 deferred to morning
[x] Task list updated - added 2 items from today's meetings
[x] Calendar reviewed - 9am meeting needs prep, doc drafted
[x] Tomorrow's MIT: Finish client proposal
[x] Today's wins: Completed research, had great call
[x] Desk cleared
[x] Said 'Shutdown complete'

--Evening: Thought about proposal popped up, reminded myself it's captured, let it go--

scripts_templates.title: Time Blocking Template
scripts_templates.context: Plan your day in advance by assigning every hour to a specific activity
scripts_templates.template:
DATE: ___

MORNING BLOCK (___am - ___am):
[_____] Deep Work: ___

MID-MORNING (___am - ___pm):
[_____] ___

LUNCH + RECOVERY:
[_____] ___

AFTERNOON BLOCK 1 (___pm - ___pm):
[_____] ___

AFTERNOON BLOCK 2 (___pm - ___pm):
[_____] Shallow work batch: email, messages, admin

SHUTDOWN (___pm):
[ ] Complete shutdown ritual

RULES:
- If a block goes over, adjust remaining blocks
- If something urgent appears, swap blocks, don't abandon
- Protect deep work blocks at all costs
scripts_templates.example_filled:
DATE: Monday Feb 3

MORNING BLOCK (6:00am - 9:00am):
[x] Deep Work: Write product specification

MID-MORNING (9:00am - 11:00am):
[x] Team standup + collaborative work

LUNCH + RECOVERY:
[x] Walk, no phone, actual rest

AFTERNOON BLOCK 1 (12:30pm - 2:30pm):
[x] Deep Work: Code review and architecture

AFTERNOON BLOCK 2 (2:30pm - 4:00pm):
[x] Shallow batch: 45 emails processed, slack caught up

SHUTDOWN (4:00pm):
[x] Ritual complete, evening protected

books.title: Deep Work
books.author: Cal Newport
books.key_takeaway: In a distracted world, the ability to focus deeply is both rare and valuable

books.title: A World Without Email
books.author: Cal Newport
books.key_takeaway: Rethink workflows to reduce the constant communication drain

podcasts.title: Deep Questions Podcast
podcasts.key_takeaway: Weekly advice on deep work, digital minimalism, and the deep life

masters.name: James Clear
key_principles: You do not rise to the level of your goals. You fall to the level of your systems.
Every action is a vote for the type of person you wish to become.
Habits are the compound interest of self-improvement.
Make it obvious, attractive, easy, and satisfying.
The task of building a good habit is like cultivating a delicate flower one day at a time.
Success is the product of daily habits, not once-in-a-lifetime transformations.
daily_practices: Stack new habits onto existing ones
Make good habits obvious and easy
Track habits visually—never break the chain

worked_examples.title: Building a Habit Stack
worked_examples.scenario: You want to build multiple new habits but they keep falling apart after a few days.
worked_examples.framework_applied: Habit Stacking + The Four Laws of Behavior Change
step_by_step: Identify a strong existing habit as an anchor (e.g., morning coffee)
Create a habit stack formula: 'After I [CURRENT HABIT], I will [NEW HABIT]'
Make it obvious: Put cues in your environment
Make it attractive: Pair with something you enjoy
Make it easy: Start with 2-minute version
Make it satisfying: Track with visual marker (X on calendar)
Never miss twice: One skip is an accident, two is a new habit
worked_examples.outcome: New habits stick because they're anchored to existing routines and optimized for your brain's habit loops

scripts_templates.title: Habit Stacking Formula Template
scripts_templates.context: Use to attach new habits to existing routines for automatic execution
scripts_templates.template:
ANCHOR HABIT (already automatic):
___

NEW HABIT TO BUILD:
___

HABIT STACK FORMULA:
'After I [ANCHOR], I will [NEW HABIT].'

MAKE IT OBVIOUS:
- Cue placement: ___

MAKE IT ATTRACTIVE:
- Temptation bundle: ___

MAKE IT EASY:
- 2-minute version: ___

MAKE IT SATISFYING:
- Immediate reward: ___
- Tracking method: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
ANCHOR HABIT: Morning coffee

NEW HABIT: Journaling

FORMULA: 'After I pour my morning coffee, I will write one sentence in my journal.'

MAKE IT OBVIOUS:
- Journal placed next to coffee maker

MAKE IT ATTRACTIVE:
- I only drink coffee while journaling (temptation bundle)

MAKE IT EASY:
- 2-minute version: Just one sentence minimum

MAKE IT SATISFYING:
- Immediate: The coffee I love + completion feeling
- Tracking: X on wall calendar above desk

scripts_templates.title: Identity-Based Habit Design
scripts_templates.context: Design habits that reinforce who you want to become
scripts_templates.template:
WHO DO I WANT TO BECOME?
I am a person who ___

WHAT WOULD THAT PERSON DO?
A person like that would ___

SMALLEST ACTION THAT PROVES THIS IDENTITY:
___

DAILY HABIT:
Every day I will ___ because I am a person who ___

EVIDENCE COLLECTION:
Each time I do this, I prove to myself that ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
WHO DO I WANT TO BECOME?
I am a person who is healthy and fit.

WHAT WOULD THAT PERSON DO?
A person like that would move their body daily.

SMALLEST ACTION:
Put on workout clothes every morning.

DAILY HABIT:
Every day I will put on workout clothes after brushing teeth because I am a person who prioritizes health.

EVIDENCE COLLECTION:
Each time I do this, I prove to myself that I'm the kind of person who shows up for their health.

books.title: Atomic Habits
books.author: James Clear
books.key_takeaway: Small habits compound into remarkable results over time

podcasts.title: James Clear on Tim Ferriss
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep dive into the systems behind building lasting habits

masters.name: Tim Ferriss
key_principles: Focus on being productive instead of busy.
Pareto principle: 80% of outputs come from 20% of inputs.
What we fear doing most is usually what we most need to do.
The question isn't 'What do I want?' It's 'What would excite me?'
Lack of time is lack of priorities.
The opposite of happiness is not sadness—it's boredom.
daily_practices: Identify the 20% of activities producing 80% of results
Do the most important task before 11am

worked_examples.title: The 80/20 Work Audit
worked_examples.scenario: You're working 50+ hours but output doesn't match effort.
step_by_step: List all your activities from the past week with hours spent
Rate each: Which produced 80% of your results/income?
Identify the vital few (usually 2-3 activities)
Ask: What if I could only do these 2-3 things?
Eliminate: What activities produced <20% of value?
Automate: What can be systematized?
Delegate: What can someone else do for you?
worked_examples.outcome: Cut work hours by 40% while increasing output by eliminating low-value activities

scripts_templates.title: 80/20 Analysis Template
scripts_templates.context: Use weekly to identify your highest-leverage activities
scripts_templates.template:
ACTIVITIES THIS WEEK:
1. ___ (___hrs) - Result: ___
2. ___ (___hrs) - Result: ___
3. ___ (___hrs) - Result: ___
[Continue for all activities]

TOP 20% (Vital Few):
___

BOTTOM 80% (Trivial Many):
___

ELIMINATE:
___

AUTOMATE:
___

DELEGATE:
___

NEXT WEEK: Spend 80% of time on ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
ACTIVITIES THIS WEEK:
1. Client calls (8hrs) - Result: $15k closed
2. Email (12hrs) - Result: Mostly reactive
3. Content creation (4hrs) - Result: 2 leads
4. Admin (6hrs) - Result: Required but low value
5. Meetings (10hrs) - Result: 1 productive, 4 waste

TOP 20% (Vital Few):
- Client calls, content creation

BOTTOM 80%:
- Most email, admin, 4/5 meetings

ELIMINATE:
- 4 unproductive meetings

AUTOMATE:
- Email templates, scheduling

DELEGATE:
- Admin to VA

NEXT WEEK: 80% time on calls + content

books.title: The 4-Hour Workweek
books.author: Tim Ferriss
books.key_takeaway: Escape the 9-5, live anywhere, join the new rich through 80/20 thinking

podcasts.title: The Tim Ferriss Show
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep-dive interviews with world-class performers on their routines and habits

masters.name: David Allen
key_principles: Your mind is for having ideas, not holding them.
You can do anything, but not everything.
The two-minute rule: If it takes less than two minutes, do it now.
Your brain is a terrible office—get everything out of it.
Review is the secret sauce of GTD.
You don't manage time. You manage your actions within time.
daily_practices: Capture everything into a trusted system
Weekly review: get clear, get current, get creative

worked_examples.title: Building a Trusted Capture System
worked_examples.scenario: You have ideas and tasks swirling in your head, causing stress and dropped balls.
step_by_step: Choose your capture tools: physical notepad, phone app, or both
Capture everything: Every thought, idea, task, reminder - get it out of your head
Process daily: For each item, ask 'What is this?' and 'What's the next action?'
Two-minute rule: If it takes less than 2 minutes, do it now
Organize the rest: Calendar (time-specific), Next Actions (context-based), Projects (multi-step outcomes)
Weekly review: Every week, process all inboxes, review all projects, get clear
Trust the system: Once it's captured, stop thinking about it
worked_examples.outcome: Your mind is clear because everything is in a system you trust. Stress decreases, focus increases.

scripts_templates.title: GTD Weekly Review Checklist
scripts_templates.context: Use every week to maintain your productivity system
scripts_templates.template:
GET CLEAR:
[ ] Collect loose papers and materials
[ ] Empty your head - capture any open loops
[ ] Process all inboxes to zero

GET CURRENT:
[ ] Review next actions lists - mark complete/delete
[ ] Review calendar (past 2 weeks) - anything to capture?
[ ] Review calendar (next 2 weeks) - prep needed?
[ ] Review projects list - any stuck?
[ ] Review Waiting For list - follow up needed?
[ ] Review Someday/Maybe list - activate anything?

GET CREATIVE:
[ ] Review goals and areas of focus
[ ] Is there anything bold I should add?
[ ] What would make next week a 10/10?

COMPLETION: All inboxes at zero, all lists current, feeling clear.
scripts_templates.example_filled:
[x] Collected papers from desk and bag
[x] Brain dump: 7 items captured
[x] Email at zero, notes processed
[x] Next actions reviewed - 5 complete, 3 deleted
[x] Past calendar reviewed - 2 follow-ups captured
[x] Upcoming: Big presentation Thursday - prep added
[x] Projects: Website launch stuck - scheduled focus time
[x] Waiting: 3 items need follow-up Monday
[x] Someday: Activated learning Spanish - scheduled first session
[x] Goals reviewed - on track
[x] Bold add: Reach out to dream client
[x] Perfect week: Ship the feature + deep work daily

FEELING: Clear, calm, ready for the week.

books.title: Getting Things Done
books.author: David Allen
books.key_takeaway: The art of stress-free productivity through complete capture and trusted systems

podcasts.title: GTD Podcast
podcasts.key_takeaway: Ongoing advice for implementing and maintaining GTD

masters.name: Nir Eyal
key_principles: The opposite of distraction is not focus. It's traction.
Time management is pain management.
You can't call something a distraction unless you know what it's distracting you from.
Master internal triggers. Discomfort drives distraction.
Make time for traction. Plan your day in timeboxes.
Hack back external triggers. Remove what doesn't serve you.

worked_examples.title: Becoming Indistractable
worked_examples.scenario: You keep getting pulled into your phone, social media, and endless browsing.
step_by_step: Master internal triggers: When you feel urge to distract, ask 'What am I trying to avoid?'
Name the discomfort: Usually boredom, anxiety, or uncertainty
Surf the urge: Instead of acting on it, observe it for 10 minutes - it usually passes
Hack external triggers: Remove apps, turn off notifications, use website blockers
Make pacts: Effort pact (add friction), price pact (penalty for distraction), identity pact ('I don't use my phone during meals')
Schedule traction: If it's not on your calendar, it's not protected
worked_examples.outcome: Distraction becomes a choice, not an automatic response. You regain control of your attention.

scripts_templates.title: Distraction Trigger Journal
scripts_templates.context: Use to understand and master what drives your distraction
scripts_templates.template:
WHEN: (time of distraction)
WHAT I WAS DOING:
INTERNAL TRIGGER: (what discomfort was I avoiding?)
- [ ] Boredom
- [ ] Anxiety
- [ ] Uncertainty
- [ ] Fatigue
- [ ] Other: ___

EXTERNAL TRIGGER: (what pulled my attention?)
- [ ] Notification
- [ ] Person
- [ ] Environmental cue
- [ ] Other: ___

WHAT I DISTRACTED WITH:

WHAT I'LL DO DIFFERENTLY:
___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
WHEN: 2:30pm
WHAT I WAS DOING: Working on difficult report
INTERNAL TRIGGER: [x] Uncertainty - wasn't sure how to proceed
EXTERNAL TRIGGER: [x] Phone on desk
WHAT I DISTRACTED WITH: Twitter for 25 minutes
WHAT I'LL DO DIFFERENTLY: 
1. Phone in drawer during deep work
2. When uncertain, write down 'What specifically am I stuck on?' before allowing break

books.title: Indistractable
books.author: Nir Eyal
books.key_takeaway: How to control your attention and choose your life

books.title: Hooked
books.author: Nir Eyal
books.key_takeaway: Understanding how products capture attention (to defend against it)

podcasts.title: Nir and Far
podcasts.key_takeaway: Ongoing research and advice on behavioral design and attention

daily_insights: What gets scheduled gets done. If it's not on your calendar, it's not real.
Your first hour sets the tone for your day. Win the morning.
Multitasking is a myth. It's just fast switching that destroys focus.
The most productive people aren't busier. They're more focused.
Deep work produces results. Shallow work produces busyness.
Every time you check your phone, you pay a 23-minute attention tax.
Energy management matters more than time management.
The hardest part is starting. Action creates motivation.
Saying yes to one thing means saying no to everything else.
Your to-do list should have 3 items, not 30.
skill_challenges: Do 90 minutes of deep work with zero interruptions.
Turn off all notifications for 4 hours. Notice how often you want to check.
Identify your top 3 tasks for tomorrow before you end today.
Use the 2-minute rule: anything under 2 minutes, do it now.
Batch all email/messages into 2-3 check times today.
Single-task for your entire morning. No switching.
Identify one time-wasting activity. Eliminate it today.
Plan tomorrow using time blocks. Follow the plan.
Do your hardest task first thing in the morning.
Review your week: What 20% of activities produced 80% of results?
